Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Digital Cranial Atlas of Pachycephalosaurid Dinosaurs
Award.AbstractNarration:
EAGER: A Digital Cranial Atlas of Pachycephalosaurid Dinosaurs
Mark Goodwin
University of California, Berkeley

The Pachycephalosauria, or dome-headed dinosaurs, are characterized by a distinctive highly inflated dome with associated skull ornamentation. They are known primarily from the Upper Cretaceous (100-64 million years ago) Western Interior of North America and central Asia. Despite increasing sample sizes of domes, skulls and partial skulls in museum collections, considerable uncertainty and debate persist among students of pachycephalosaurs in regard to individual variation, ontogeny (growth and development), dome function, and systematic (how they are related to one another). Morphological or shape disparity between growth stages is increased by extended neoteny and late stage allometric growth in the Marginocephalia (pachycephalosaurids + ceratopsids), resulting in juveniles that look very different from adults of the same taxa. This pattern of extreme cranial growth trajectories potentially obscures evolutionary relationships, contributes to uncertain phylogenetic character selection, and may inflate dinosaur diversity estimates leading up to the terminal Cretaceous extinction event. Thus, it is critical to identify the relative growth stage of a pachycephalosaur cranium preceding any advanced analysis of comparative cranial morphology, variation, ontogeny and systematics.

This project will begin to build a digital cranial atlas of North American pachycephalosaurid dinosaurs using non-destructive high-resolution X-ray computed tomography (HRCT) to: (1) confirm internal and external patterns of growth and development and determine the extent of cranial (skull) ontogenetic (growth) variation; (2) reevaluate and test opposing hypotheses and associated taxonomic, paleobiologic, and paleobiogeographic questions; (3) enhance recent histological studies and expand comparative cranial morphometric analyses; (4) advance evolutionary biology, paleontology, public education and outreach by serving the digital cranial atlas on www.ucmp.berkeley.edu.
Proof of concept test scans and limited full scans of select pachycephalosaurid skulls were confirmed by the PI at the University of Texas High-Resolution X-ray CT Facility (UTCT). Skulls of nearly all pachycephalosaurid species in the Museum of the Rockies, Royal Ontario Museum, Royal Tyrrell Museum of Paleontology, and the UC Museum of Paleontology reflecting 100% of North American pachycephalosaur diversity will be accessed for this study. The PI will be using a NSF sponsored facility to do this work and will be developing the prototype of a larger geoinformatics project.

Broader Impacts: This project will serve a broader audience in multiple ways. Students from the UC Berkeley undergraduate research apprentice program (URAP) will be engaged in building the digital atlas thus gaining new skills in digitization and engaging directly in scientific research from a paleobiological perspective. This project will serve to broaden their knowledge base and research experience as a UC Berkeley undergraduate. The PI will oversee the development of a user's guide to the atlas, which will allow the data to be used by students at both the high school and undergraduate levels and within a case study to be developed for UCMP's Understanding Science website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pachycephalosaurs, popularly known as dome-headed dinosaurs, are a group of bipedal ornithischian dinosaurs characterized by a distinctive and greatly thickened bony dome on the top of their skulls. Cranial ornaments composed of bumps, nodes and horns often surround the dome and cover nearly the surface of the skull. Extreme modification of these dinosaur skulls occurred as these dinosaurs approached about 50% of adult size, resulting in juveniles looking very different then their parents and adults. As a result, paleontologists historically named many of these dome-headed dinosaurs new species erroneously based on ontogenetic features that change dramatically as the animals grow up into adults of the same species.

It remained challenging for paleontologists to recognize younger individuals because these dinosaurs grow their skulls very differently than modern mammals, birds and crocodilians today. Identifying true adult dinosaurs is a challenge since they are found in significantly fewer numbers in the fossil record and it is likely we have underestimated the size of adult skulls for some species. Sutural patterns along contacts between individual bones of the pachycephalosaur skull are often not visible on the outside, or dorsal surface, of these “dome-heads” and appear closed, indicative of adult growth as interpreted in modern animals. Upon closer examination by cutting a piece of the fossil skull, gluing it down onto a glass slide, grinding it down to about one tenth of one millimeter, and looking at it under a specialized microscope, paleontologists realized that the internal tissues were also very different from any known modern animals.

Computer tomography, or CT scanning, is another analytical technique available to paleontologists to study the bones of pachycephalosaur skulls and other vertebrate fossils without cutting up the fossil and compliments 2D hard tissue histology. CT scanning reveals fine scale patterns and textures of the skull in 3D and allows, for the first time, the assignment of the relative age of many of these pachycephalosaur skulls. In other words, paleontologists can determine if these dinosaurs were juveniles, subadults, or adults. These terms more accurately reflect a growth continuum than actual growth stages, but are critical for testing various hypotheses on the evolutionary relationships between different pachycephalosaur species, as well as ideas about dinosaur growth and behavior. For example, for over fifty years, pachycephalosaurs were often portrayed using their bony domes as battering rams like bighorn sheep. Using CT scanning, we were able to demonstrate that the structures previously identified as giving these dinosaurs a biomechanical advantage for head-butting, were in fact a result of the domes growing really fast and these structures, or bony fibers, were absent in skulls approaching the adult size of older individuals who would engage in this head-butting behavior. Bone also responds to stresses as a result of such a violent encounter. This is how and why a broken bone will heal. The CT scanning in this research project did not reveal any evidence of these stresses from head to head contact. While they might have head-butted, there is no evidence in this study to support this interpretation. We conclude that the pachycephalosaur skull and dome were used for visual communication so that juveniles could recognize other juveniles and adults could recognize other adults since the bumps, nodes and horns are right on top of their faces.
